sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Consider the equation f(x) = 2x³ + 9x² - 3x - 10. Use the Newton-Raphson method to find the root of the equation correct to 3 decimal places, for an initial guess of x = 1.5.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x). 

f(x) = 2x³ + 9x² - 3x - 10

The derivative, f'(x), is:

f'(x) = 6x² + 18x - 3

Now, we apply the Newton-Raphson formula:

x_new = x_old - f(x_old) / f'(x_old)

We start with the initial guess x_old = 1.5 and iterate until we reach the desired accuracy (3 decimal places).

1st iteration:
x_new = 1.5 - (2(1.5)³ + 9(1.5)² - 3(1.5) - 10) / (6(1.5)² + 18(1.5) - 3)
x_new ≈ 1.276

2nd iteration:
x_new = 1.276 - (2(1.276)³ + 9(1.276)² - 3(1.276) - 10) / (6(1.276)² + 18(1.276) - 3)
x_new ≈ 1.256

3rd iteration:
x_new = 1.256 - (2(1.256)³ + 9(1.256)² - 3(1.256) - 10) / (6(1.256)² + 18(1.256) - 3)
x_new ≈ 1.255

Since the difference between the 2nd and 3rd iteration is less than 0.001, we can stop here. The root of the equation f(x) = 2x³ + 9x² - 3x - 10, correct to 3 decimal places, is approximately x ≈ 1.255.
